column1: text
Scooby-Doo’s real name is Scoobert Doo.
The first Scooby-Doo series, Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!, premiered in 1969.
Scooby-Doo was created by Joe Ruby and Ken Spears.
Shaggy and Scooby act scared because their characters were designed to add humor to the mysteries.
Scooby Snacks are portrayed as a tasty treat that Scooby and Shaggy love, though their ingredients are never fully revealed.
Shaggy is known for his enormous appetite, which is played for comedic effect.
Fred is usually the one who drives the Mystery Machine.
Scooby-Doo is generally depicted as seven years old in dog years, though his age varies across media.
Scooby can speak limited English, often mixing words with his signature “Ruh-roh!” style.
Velma frequently loses her glasses because it's part of her character’s clumsy charm.
Fred is often shown as the leader of Mystery Inc. during investigations.
Daphne is portrayed as brave and resourceful, despite often ending up in tricky situations.
Scooby-Doo is a Great Dane, although his appearance is stylized for animation.
Shaggy became a vegetarian in later adaptations to match his voice actor’s lifestyle.
Fred’s full name is Frederick Herman Jones.
Scooby has several family members, including Scrappy-Doo and Scooby-Dum.
Most villains in the series are regular people wearing elaborate costumes to scare others.
The Mystery Machine is a brightly colored van used by the gang to travel to each mystery.
Velma is typically the smartest member of the group and often solves the mysteries.
Daphne’s character evolves over the years into a martial artist, reporter, and skilled fighter.
Shaggy’s best friend is Scooby, and their friendship drives much of the series’ humor.
Fred is known for setting traps, although they often fail in unexpected ways.
The show uses comedic fear rather than real danger to keep it family-friendly.
Scooby-Doo occasionally gains temporary bravery when offered a Scooby Snack.
Mystery Inc. usually unmasks villains to reveal their true identities at the end.
The gang solves supernatural mysteries that always turn out to have logical explanations.
Scooby and Shaggy often try to avoid danger but end up helping solve the mystery anyway.
Velma’s catchphrase “Jinkies!” is one of the most recognizable in the series.
The series has gone through many reboots but always keeps the core team together.
Scooby-Doo remains popular because of its mix of comedy, mystery, and memorable characters.
